If there is anyting that I have against Lear is the three shift pattern.  For two weeks you have to work mornings, then afternoons, then nights, which was very disruptive to one's sleep pattern.  A typical day at work: foams in the shape of car seats are provided.  The hog-ringers would pull the leather over the foam and attach the leather to the foam with hog-rings.  They would then put the finished seats on a stand.  The heat gunners (myself) would then take a seat from the stand and apply heat to the leather and smooth out any wrinkles with a flat ivory stick. I would then place the finished seat on another stand for the inspectors. If the inspectors are happy they would put the seat in a plastic cover and put on another stand.  Once this stand is full it is taken away to be loaded on a lorry.  If the inspectors are not happy eg. a few hog-rings are missing or the leather is burnt then they report it to my team leader who in turn would notify us to correct the problem.  In the case of burnt leather, the leather has to be removed and replaced with a new one which can be costly to the company if too many seats are burnt.  A bad day for me is when I burn too many seats in one shift and receiving a reprimand from the manager. This happened to me only once and I've been very careful ever since.
